What's the first thing that a vendor could do to make sure this catastrophe doesn't happen?
Well, obviously you need to test your software.

Well, the first most important thing:
business continuity disaster recovery planning.
Everyone needs to do this.
You need to assume everything will fail.
Look at every part of the system
and imagine what happens if that thing doesn't work.
And then figure out, how would we recover from that?
So that's the basic planning part of it.
And one of the most important parts of that
is having good backups

So for instance, here's my system operating.

to very quickly recover that system
back to the state that it was in when I did the last backup.
Or if I have lots of these systems,
maybe what I need is a master image
that I can then restore across all of these very quickly.

That is, assume the operating system is not even on this system.
As if it was just brand new bare metal out of the box,

That will particularly make sense in cases where everyone uses

So that has to be in place,

The longer you wait to apply it, the longer you're exposed.

Another one that you need to consider is

Keep It Simple, Stupid.
How simple do you want to make it?
Well, I've said before that complexity is the enemy of security.
So we'd like to keep the system simple if we can.
